results.title: Hobbing a spur gear. Part I. Setting of the change gears
results.creator_credit: F.E. Brooker and Emerson Yorke Studio
results.brief_description: Shows the factors governing the selection of the hob; how to select change-gear combinations for speed, feed, and index; how to identify the correct gears; how to mount the change gears; how to adjust for backlash; and how the change-gear strains are interrelated.

results.title: Hobart town
results.creator_credit: Hugh McInnes, Maslyn Williams, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: A description of Hobart, Tasmania and its surrounding districts, which are crowded with historic buildings and monuments dating back to the first settlers and convicts.

results.title: Hobart: island capital
results.brief_description: The tourist attractions of Hobart, the peaceful capital in the Derwent Valley under the shadow of Mt Wellington. Although many attractive new buildings are rising in the business centre of the city, the old buildings with their historical associations retain the greatest charm. The sea and the docks are only a few minutes from the city and the Royal Hobart Regatta is a highlight of the Tasmanian year.

results.title: The Hoarder
results.creator_credit: Evelyn Lambart and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A Birdland fantasy, by animation artist Evelyn Lambart, about a bluejay who takes whatever his beak can grasp and carry. Into his secret cache go berries, birds’ eggs, nests and all. Even the sun in the sky is unsafe from his consuming greed. But, as in her film Fine Feathers, there is a moral tucked away. The bluejay learns a lesson, and Birdland returns to normal. Suitable for primary school level

results.title: Hitler: anatomy of a dicatatorship
results.brief_description: Adolph Hitler became legal head of the German government in 1933. To a nation torn by economic, political and spiritual crises, he promised strong leadership and a policy of revenge against supposed enemies, at home and abroad. With little opposition, Hitler soon made himself the master of Europe. Before the Allies finally defeated him, he would be responsible for the deaths of over 350 million people, an unmatched record of dictatorial brutality. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: The History of writing
results.brief_description: Divided into four parts. Discusses and illustrates the origins of picture writing; the writing systems of China, Mesopotamia, and Egypt; the emergence of the first real alphabet in Palestine and Syria; the spread of this alphabet to Greece and Rome; and the development of the Roman script through the Middle Ages until the invention of printing.

results.title: The History of Totalitarianism
results.brief_description: Images are flashed in rapid succession of tyrants, artefacts and symbols of oppression from the days of Cheops to the present, to portray a quick history of man’s oppression of man. A musical score of contrasting rhythms underscores the philosophical message. Without narration.

results.title: The History of the helicopter
results.creator_credit: Sarah Erulkar and Shell Film Unit
results.brief_description: The growth of vertical flight from the early experiments of Leonardo da Vinci and others to the development of the modern helicopter. A feature of the film is a sequence made up of extracts from early newsreels.
